textHTML:
Discounting the positive is a cognitive distortion where we brush aside, downplay, or even ignore the important positive aspects of our lives. Instead, we focus on flaws and negatives, dismissing real successes and achievements—even when they’re significant.

This can show up in many areas: work, relationships, health, or personal growth. For example, someone might achieve professional recognition but dwell on small mistakes instead of taking pride in their accomplishment. Or if someone receives a compliment, they may shrug it off as unimportant or unearned.

Underestimating your own positives can make you doubt your abilities, erode confidence, and lead to dissatisfaction or even depression. Learning to spot and truly appreciate the good things in your life, and allowing yourself to celebrate your achievements, is critical for a healthier mindset.
dialogSummary: In this conversation, Person 1 devalues their recent job promotion by focusing on the upcoming responsibilities instead of celebrating the success. Person 2 highlights the importance of this achievement and offers congratulations.
dialog: I got promoted at work and now I'll be taking on new projects.
That’s fantastic news—congratulations! Which projects will you be handling?
They’re quite challenging, and I have a lot of work ahead. It feels like I’m just piling on more responsibilities.
I know it’s a challenge, but you’ve reached a major milestone in your career! This is a great chance to grow and develop.
